The Age of Iran - The Birth of the Nuclear Agreement between Iran and 5 + 1 in 2015 has brought Iran's relationship with the international community into a new phase. After years of unilateral sanctions by the United Nations, the European Union and the United States, it has finally become the basis for an end to Iran's political impasse, the opening of economic cooperation with other countries, and the end point for securing Iran's case internationally. However, the quiet days of my life were short and its economic gains for Iran could more or less be compared to a miraculous government. The presence of US President Donald Trump in the White House has disrupted not only the brokerage equations but also the order of many international treaties and treaties. It was in the spring of 1977 that the US withdrawal from the nuclear deal disrupted the equations of Iran and the survivors. In the past year and a half, the return of US nuclear sanctions has virtually overshadowed Iran's economic benefit from the deal.
Gholamreza Ansari, Deputy Minister of Economic Diplomacy at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, in a detailed interview, describes the difficulties of the Department, especially in the days of sanctions, and the unprecedented efforts that the State Department is making to improve the country's economic situation. Ansari, who has a background in the Iranian embassy in India, Russia and Britain, said: "The ministry has never been so involved in economic matters for the past 30 years."
Iran's Deputy Foreign Minister for Economic Diplomacy said in the interview that Iran would pass through the hard embargo, and that if national cohesion and unity prevailed and national interests prevailed over factional decision-making, it would be easier for the country to impose sanctions. Read more of this interview by the newspaper Etemad.
* The Department of Economic Diplomacy can be described as a fledgling State Department deputy with both little information on how much work is being done and many criticisms of it, both right and wrong. It began in the days when we saw the return of US nuclear sanctions. How has the return of secondary sanctions affected the efficiency of the work of the Deputy Director of Economic Diplomacy?
- With the United States stepping down from Brigham, a new set of restrictions was created for Iran's foreign trade, and we were faced with some and all but none. In the most recent of these, severe restrictions have been placed on the supply of medicines and foodstuffs. However, various Donald Trump administration officials are trying to calm the world's public by symbolic measures to facilitate the delivery of drugs and foodstuffs. Iran has taken it for granted, but with the new US Treasury decision, restrictions have actually been tightened. So part of the US effort to restrict Iran's foreign trade goes back to the laws and regulations that actually put pressure on our country. This is far more significant than the US sanctions. The Americans have been very brutal and inhumane in sanctions. Even those who are prepared to work with Iran in accordance with laws and regulations and face all kinds of threats and pressure from the United States. In other countries, for example, representatives from US embassies visit and threaten them. The threat is widespread and even threatened in some cases by family and relatives. It does not fit easily with the Americans. In fact, it can be said that US behavior in threatening and intimidating others to stop working with Iran is more violent and more problematic than sanctions laws and regulations.
How successful has this American method been? Examples of these behaviors were seen in Germany and Iraq.
- One of the characteristics of Brigham was that it provided international sympathy for Iran. Prior to the nuclear deal, we saw the formation of an Iranian pharmacy atmosphere around Iran, much of which was rooted in the imposition of multilateral UN, European, and US sanctions against Iran. But after the end, we see an international solidarity and a positive mindset in favor of Iran that still exists. Even in this context of unilateral US sanctions with the potential of transboundary punishment, we come from different countries and declare that they want to work with Iran and do not accept US unilateral laws and regulations.
Of course, not accepting US unilateral regulations has virtually no impact on the final decision of non-Americans because they are afraid of entering the Iranian market because of these sanctions.
- Yes, they can do nothing in practice given that their companies and banks are economically dependent on the US market and American shareholders are active in these companies. However, there is a sense of sympathy, cooperation and harmony in them. Economic diplomacy has become much more complex and complex after the US nuclear sanctions have been lifted. US threats, in their place, are also effective because they also raise personal and family issues. Therefore, even if some want to do business with Iran within the framework of laws and regulations, they face US obstacles.
* Has the State Department taken the initiative to overcome these obstacles?
- What I said does not mean that there is no opportunity. Fortunately, the State Department has been able to organize the commute to and from the country and we have had some very good successes. Today, we are witnessing the shaping of the ways in which we might have expected the Iranian economy to take these paths for many years. Today and now, neighbors are the main focus of Iran's foreign trade. Over 50 to 55 percent of our foreign trade is with our neighbors.
* Is this figure after the US sanctions are back?
- Yes, I mean right now. This is a huge success in reforming the overall structure of the country's trade, and from the outset, neighbors should have been our top priority. We have recently seen the Preferential Trade Agreement with Eurasia. It was a great success for the government to implement this agreement at this point. In this market of 200 million, we have access to 500 and Andy's goods, which is a long and positive step, and its importance is doubled when we know that this was done during the period of unilateral US sanctions.
Q: Given the US toughening of the sanctions that you mentioned in your remarks, what mechanism did we set out to work with its neighbors under sanctions that reached 55 percent of foreign trade with neighbors?
Neighbors have always been an asset and an advantage, but perhaps because they have been easier to work with in the West and beyond, they have chosen the West in recent years. Sanctions have made us focus on easy access today. We communicate with our neighboring markets a distance away. In these markets there is a great demand for Iranian goods.
* In your remarks, you emphasize the need to institutionalize business with neighbors. What is the mechanism by which this level of trade is guaranteed to continue?
- This institutionalization must be achieved through the agreements we sign with these countries. Agreements such as customs, transit or preferential trade agreements. These agreements can serve as the same guarantee as you mentioned. We currently export over $ 10-12 billion to Iraq. But these exports can always be vulnerable. The future of this business can be guaranteed when we come to agreements with Iraq that are within the framework of those agreements and not on the basis of market and day-to-day trade.
* What is the State Department's roadmap for facilitating the signing of these agreements?
- The Foreign Ministry is looking for precisely this. In the matter of preferential trade agreement with Eurasia, the State Department has a central role in convincing the country.
* Last week, in a similar comment, you emphasized the need for such agreements with Iraq. What steps have you taken in this direction?
- We are Egypt to reach these structures with Iraq and one of them is the preferred trade agreement we are looking for.
Q: What issues have prevented the Iraqis from reaching this agreement, given our deep and bilateral political and economic relations with Baghdad?
- There are obstacles on the other side (Iraq).
* What are the obstacles, for example?
- They are resisting and seem to be concerned about the imbalance in their export and import volumes with Iran. Our exports to Iraq are $ 13 billion and Iraq's exports to Iran are $ 250 million. We also need to pay attention to our business concerns and find ways to increase its exports to Iran. Another issue is to persuade domestic markets. That we have gained so many concessions, we must also confer concessions. Convincing here is a problem.
* Turkey is one of the countries with which we have a preferential agreement that you name as a guarantee of continuity of trade. Has this agreement brought the business relationship to a level of satisfaction?
- The preferential trade agreement with Turkey is not as active as expected by the two countries. We should also move towards activating this preferential trade agreement. Turkey is a very important partner for us. So we need to find ways to make these connections more institutionalized and active. The domestic market is needed to help us with these institutionalization.
* Convincing the domestic market is something you both mentioned in the discussion between Iraq and Turkey. There are similar concerns about Afghanistan. With Iran under a boycott and many domestic traders complaining about business uncertainty why the domestic market lacks the necessary support. Is the State Department responsible for this or is it the responsibility of other agencies?
- The title of our post is economic diplomacy. The meaning is that our role is to facilitate, to strive for understanding. We have no role in change. We hope we can play our role well and be able to make a difference more than our own.
* Of course, expectations from the State Department in the economic sector are high.
Expectations skyrocket. This is quite clear. You hear a lot of criticism from us in different days and places, but we try not to go into a continuous cycle of responses because we at the State Department haveIn our role, we have exerted all our efforts in the field of economic diplomacy. This is a very important role, but our tools are not as they should be.
* What tools, for example?
- During the post-revolutionary period, the State Department has never paid much attention to economic issues and their entry into it. For the past 30 years while I have been in the State Department, this ministry has never been concerned with economic issues in today's volume, and of course this attention and focus is a necessity for society and the country. But the tools we have are less than we expect. We are increasing the capacity and training of individuals in the economic field. We encourage Iranian agencies abroad to do more economic work, but in any case, we need serious changes in the eyes of the country. If our eyes do not change, our role as economic diplomacy may sometimes not be very effective.
* Is one of the areas in which the look inside should change is attracting foreign investment?
- Certainly. Mr Zarif has always emphasized at various meetings that there were golden conditions for attracting foreign investment in the aftermath, and foreign investors offered credit and investment lines. In fact, this was a very good fortune, but the money needed to enter the country requires a mechanism, but the mechanisms are resisting. In some cases this legal provision did not have the necessary adaptation to the new situation or in that organization the current mechanism was not needed and others did not have the required rial to do so. For these reasons, we have lost some opportunities for foreigners to work in Iran. So acceptance, preparation, and looking inside are very important.
* After Trump's withdrawal from Brigham, some experts within the country believed that given the new American president's entrepreneurial spirit, perhaps Trump would not have easily come out of the deal if the US economy had been greater than Brajam. To what extent do you accept this?
- The reality is that this is not the case. Today, those who gave everything to Trump cannot trust Trump. Donald Trump is not trustworthy at all. Look at the status of the countries that paid Trump everything he wanted. In just one phase of some countries, $ 400 billion of capital went to the United States. Do they trust the United States? no. The reason some of them are back today and want to define a new space with Iran is because they are frustrated by Trump and have found the truth that he is unreliable. You hear Mr. Trump's speeches, the question comes to you, how do the American people, who are great people, feel about having such a president? Trump's words aren't that complicated, of course. A careful look at the literature he uses, as well as how he deals with regional and world issues, show that even his friends cannot count on him or trust him.
* With the US withdrawing from the nuclear deal and the return of secondary sanctions, public opinion has raised the question that sanctions were not one of the goals of the lifting of sanctions. Do you believe that the Department of Economic Diplomacy of the State Department believes that the boycott is a major problem for our economy, or that the Iranian economy has structural flaws that, incidentally, have contributed to these economic upheavals and deficits in the last two years?
- I do not agree with your introduction.
* Which part do you disagree with?
That the goal was economic.
One of the goals of the economic, economic, and economic goals of Iran was to lift sanctions.
- At all, you certainly remember that era when we had UN sanctions and the multilateral restrictions and sanctions of that era put a lot of pressure on us. But in the nuclear negotiations, we sought our inalienable right to enrich. Our point was that the world should recognize Iran's enrichment. This was more important to us than economic issues.
I do not deny this, but it also had an economic purpose.
- Bridget had accounted for her goals. I do not mean to say that in the economic sphere, it should have been accounted for. I have achieved many great goals in the political field. No country in the world has the UN and UN Security Council authorization to enrich, but Iran does. These were the results, where did it come from?
* The political outcome was secure, but the economic outcome was also defined.
- Look what I said was a breakthrough. No country has been internationally included in Chapter 7 of the Charter that has come out healthy. As a result, all UN resolutions went away one night. No politician in the world would believe this. These are the achievements of Bram. Of course, any contract at the brokerage level cannot be absolutely positive and complete. It may have shortcomings, and part of it may be economic.
* Of course, before the United States left Brajam, we would derive from Brajam a relative economic benefit, and this is sometimes claimed by the presence of large European and non-European companies in Iran.
- The bottom line was political and economic. After attending the White House, Donald Trump felt he had gone to America with a big hat and started opposing it. Naturally, the United States would have the most economic pressure on Iran from the economic path. Even in the Obama administration, the Americans began economic pressures shortly after they agreed. So Donald Trump's move in the US policy toward Iran was not new. The US problem with Iran was not just the end, but the US pursuing dozens of other problems with Iran. Despite the economic pressures resulting from America's withdrawal from the brigade, it cannot be said that the brigade has not made any gains. It would have been a great victory for Iran, but it also had some shortcomings. I have never seen anyone claim to have a perfect contract, but at the same time we cannot ignore the benefits of the contract. The space that was created after the brigade was a very positive atmosphere. Despite the missteps and pressure from the Americans, the space was a very good space, and maybe we didn't make the most of it. By the time Mr Trump arrived and he had withdrawn from the deal.
* The Americans, citing economic statistics on rising inflation in Iran, claim that their policy of maximum pressure will eventually put Iran on the table with economic tools. How do you assess the economic impact of this policy on Iran?
- Donald Trump has launched a new policy of maximum pressure against Iran as he steps down, but the truth is that despite the claims you made today, the United States has come to the conclusion that the maximum pressure has not responded. The government has made economic gains despite the sanctions and has dominated the country's economic development. Today, even international organizations are talking about the economic growth of Iran next year. This shows that America's maximum pressure will not work and certainly will not. I think this policy will even have the opposite effect for the US. This year, after 40 years of what everyone had hoped for after the revolution, this year is the year when the government announces a budget separate from oil. This was the long-held dream of the forty years of the revolution.
* How realistic this wish is in the realm of action for a country whose economy has always been dependent on oil. It is now one of our main conditions for Europeans to stay on the brink of selling oil and restoring it.
- This year is the first year we have introduced an oil-free budget. If we can move forward with the support of the nation and go through this period, it will be a major change in the country's economy. In my opinion, the nation has always supported the state, the system, the system and the sovereignty, and if that support continues, we can go through this era without oil.
* What time period do you mean?
- Whenever our imagination is comfortable that we can run the country without oil.
* Mr. Ansari is virtually impossible to run a country without oil in the short term.
- I am not saying this is not difficult and simple but it is very difficult but it is not impossible for people like me to go through the war. Maybe if you asked me in the early years of the war, could this giant Saddam Hussein, who is behind him all over the world economically and financially, could be saved? It was very difficult to give a definitive answer. You could only answer in silence and pray for victory. Things are no tougher now than in the war years. Rather, the conditions are much more lucrative for us to be able to cross this stage and to imagine that we can live without oil.
* US policy is to zero Iran's oil sales. To what extent can this policy succeed?
- Whether we strive for oil independence and the US trying to bring our oil sales down to zero is two different things. Normal oil sales are Iran's right. That doesn't mean we have to give up our right. It is our right and our nation's right to have access to large oil markets and to easily sell our oil wherever and whenever we wish. This is another debate. This year, for the first time, we are introducing an oil-free budget. This is a very difficult task, but it is not impossible at all. This year is the first year that our non-oil exports have increased relative to our oil exports. The nation also resisted and supported. Production in different sectors is on the rise. We need to provide the conditions and open the way for companies to define their financial resources. Despite the year 97 and 98, we enter growth in the year 99. While US sanctions have overshadowed our oil sales, our economy has entered a growth phase.
* In your remarks you mentioned the difficulty of passing through this period, so naturally this policy will affect the people's table. However, this table is also affected by the sanctions.
- We need to justify people and make conditions for good people.
* Justify that we enter a war period?
- No, we are going through a difficult period, and if we all help each other, we will get through it easier. If we continue to quarrel with each other, it will be even harder. If we can formulate tough conditions for good people and use more thought and expertise, we will certainly end this difficult time with the support and confidence of the people more easily.
* Officials are planning, but most of the problems are on the people's shoulders. Mr Zarif has the term economic warfare, and boycotts are termed economic warfare and terrorism. However, given the United States' efforts - of course not to say whether it is successful or not - to experience zero oil sales, people are experiencing economic hardship. As Vice President of Economic Diplomacy, you can tell us explicitly whether the Iranian people in the next one to two years will Shouldn't something happen if they have to endure a period of economic warfare?
- I think the Iranian people have gone through a period of economic warfare in the last two to three years. Mr Trump, who took office, began a serious war and economic terrorism against Iran.
Q: Do you mean that we have passed the hard line of sanctions?
- I think we've gone through a time when our currency has tripled suddenly, and if we all help the government and those who try to do it again, we'll have it easier. My emphasis is only on this part. It is a very difficult and difficult task and it needs everyone. If everyone tries, it's easier. If we don't try, it will pass, but it will get harder.
During the one and a half years since the US sanctions have returned, especially in discussing trade relations with our neighbors and major trading partners, we have tried to create a bank with terms such as "outsourcing", "local currency trading", such as Pakistan and Afghanistan. We have become more familiar with each other in common. Can you briefly tell us in which of these areas we are close to the ultimate goal and stage of implementation?
- None of this is just a phrase today, but it is in action. The use of local money, leverage, joint work and joint banking have become mechanisms. These are the things that we have been implementing and operating for the past year and a half and we have received results.
* Can you identify with which countries we have reached the implementation stage of these mechanisms?
- Today we are no longer the only sanctioned country in the world. There may not have been anyone around us in the world of sanctions at one time, but today many countries like us are in the sanctions debate: China, Russia, Turkey, Cuba, Venezuela, and so on. Any country that has not 100% bent on American demands is under sanctions. Today in the world we have launched topics that will have long-term, serious consequences for the West, such as the use of local currency. This is the literature that today, you and all your neighbors and those who are in the boycott talking about it, is new. Whether the two countries, such as Russia and Turkey, talk about trading in local currency or when they face the threat of a swift embargo, they are looking to launch a new national swap without the United States, all threatening the dollar. Today China is looking for new mechanisms with Russia, Russia with its neighbors and partners, including Turkey. These were not found in the literature of international economics.
* My question remained unanswered. With which countries have we implemented these mechanisms?
- I can only tell you that we have implemented each of these mechanisms with countries in the process. For example, poverty is no longer the case, and some of our economic organizations have raised billions of dollars.
So can we say that Iran has found a way out of US unilateral sanctions and implemented it beyond finding it?
- Yes, the accomplishments I have mentioned during this boycott period have been achieved in the last year and a half. The person who imposes the boycott is a human being and the person who is going to circumvent the boycott is a human being . But he has a way of sanctioning, but we have a thousand ways to get around sanctions. It is important for us to trust each other internally, to be consistent and to find the sides of our work. Today, the economic situation of the world is in crisis everywhere. All countries have problems with unemployment, trade deficits, and dozens of problems. So if we find these troublemakers, they will work with us, despite the pressures they have. Today we can tell a country that we buy products from you, but we cannot pay you because of bank restrictions. If you want to sell your goods to us, you must buy from us.
* Do they welcome this method?
- There is no other way than this. Iran has not been and is not a small market.
* One way is to not trade with us and not threaten US sanctions. But now you are saying that they are choosing the second more rigid way of doing business with Iran.
- They have no other way and we have no other way. We say we need to buy this item from you and need it. You import that kind of goods from that country, but you can buy that from us. If you want fertilizer, we have fertilizer and give it to you. We give him fertilizer and we get the goods we need from him. So what you refer to as literature or phrase is in operation and it's been a year and a half since we've been doing it. This is becoming more and more common. Many come and ask us to explain to us the mechanism of Iran's extermination. So there's this welcome. The important point is that in the overhead system, no financial exchange is needed. Because you have no business with the bank. That is to say, bypassing the bank sanctions that are most damaging to us.
Why don't we use the same model to work with Europeans? INSTEX has been a year and a half experiencing a lot of up and down challenges, and now everyone is talking about this mechanism. The biggest hurdle to implementing Intex was not the way to circumvent US sanctions, whether in banking or trade with Iran. Why don't we launch something like the mechanisms that you say we do with European countries, which were one of our main partners after the end? Is there no political will in Europe?
- The Europeans made a great effort, but American influence and roots in Europe were more than we imagined. At the beginning of the interview, I stated that: 1) US sanctions and 2) US behavior has become a challenge. For example, the European Bank for Development (EBRD) is ready to invest in Iran, and then we find that within twenty-four hours of its managing director denying this and saying that we were wrong. Later it is revealed that they have come to him and threatened him. For example, they told him that your child was studying in the US or threatened his wife. Even if it does so within the framework of its company rules and regulations, it will be denied privileges. They have taken some of their passports and canceled the visas that were in the passports of their children and their families. All these behaviors are due to working with Iran. This is barbaric behavior and not normal behavior. The Europeans have tried, but today, Europe is not the Europe of the past. Europe today is experiencing the worst of its life. Europe is currently embroiled in issues such as Britain's exit from the Union and economic crises. The Europeans have come to grips with the US financial system after the embargo on Iran and their efforts to continue economic cooperation with Iran. Today, they cannot implement it despite the decision they make.
* Iran's fourth step seems to be certain. Can I say from your talk about Europe's inability that we are almost disappointed that the three European countries, as our main partners, can take a step towards Iran's economic prosperity?
- The Europeans we talk to today, despite their extensive efforts, have been unable to do anything. If we do not say no steps, but what we need to answer so far have failed. They've made small moves, but it's not a convincing move. We'll have to see where their effort will go if they can. But we are determined to step four and we should not doubt this. All the officials of the Islamic Republic of Iran, from the President, the Foreign Minister, the Deputy Foreign Minister, have always insisted that if Europe fails to show the political will it calls for, Iran will take the fourth step. We hope the Europeans can come up with an initiative that will persuade Iran to stay on the brink.
Q: In your remarks on Iran's passage through the hard sanctions regime, Iran's growing trade relationship with its neighbors and Iran's oil-free budget. At the same time, Iran has fallen short of its commitments in response to a decline in counterparty commitments. If the current situation between Iran and Europe and step-by-step cuts in commitments fail, the UN Security Council resolutions, which are multilateral in the face of US sanctions, will return. The gains you are talking about will not be lost. The resolutions mean that Iran can no longer work with its neighbors and trading partners, even with mechanisms such as local currency and currency.
- We continue to be committed to the Brajam. We have never stated that we want to get out.
* The path we are in may eventually lead us and 4 + 1 to the end.
- What will happen is unclear. The brokerage is a contract that the two parties can preserve and value, and a commitment by both parties is essential. The brokerage is a multilateral contract, and one party's commitment cannot keep the contract alive. We are not the one who wants Brigham's death. We are certainly the last to say that the life of this deal will be of no use. If we take these steps today, it is not because we want to get out of it, but to keep it. We say maintaining the brokerage is the time when all of their obligations are fulfilled. If the parties fail to fulfill their obligations, there is no contract. But, as all officials have said, we are committed to it and we want it to be preserved. We hope that the survivors will fulfill their obligations in Brjam.
* You have a history of our Embassy in India. We were at a time when the Indians announced that they would definitely continue to buy oil from Iran. Then came the news that the interruption in the previous level of oil purchases from Iran was limited to the election period, and promises that things would change after the elections. There was news that Saudi Arabia would replace Iran. What is the state of our oil sales to India today and the consultations that the State Department has taken to keep it going?
- First, selling oil to India is a two-way trade. That is, if India buys oil from us, we keep its money there and buy goods from there. Far from worrying about selling our oil, Indian farmers are worried that if Iran's financial resources run out, who will supply the market for Indian crops? Will the country that India replaces with our oil also buy Indian rice and products? Iran's money in India is a source used by both parties. Under a deal between Tehran and New Delhi, the money stays in India, and if that money runs out, it means Indian sellers must also seek out new customers. So while we were benefiting from the sale of oil to India, but certainly know that Indians are more profitable than us. Hundreds of thousands of Indian farmers are hoping for this trade.
Have they also turned this hope into a pressure on the Indian government to continue buying oil from Iran?
- Yes, the Indians confirm what I said. The Indian government says it is trying to find a way to open up the business. It is a two-way trade. Of course, our non-oil exports to India continue. If they buy enough of us non-oil goods to meet their export demand, it will be a reopening. Now our export to India is good.
Is it accountable for oil exports and can it replace oil?
- no. Not yet. But if we move to exporting more Iranian non-oil goods to India, it will be ready in Iran. The Indian market is a huge market for all Iranian products. Our biggest problem right now is apple exports. We are the fifth largest apple producer in the world and the Indian market can be a good market for Iranian apple exports. Iranian fruit products have a very good market in India. Products such as petrochemicals, chemical fertilizers and all downstream Iranian petroleum products are marketed there. If we can sell these crops there, then, naturally, Indian farmers' concerns will disappear. But for the time being, our oil exports to India have made more money for us.
Q: Why haven't we come up with a bilateral mechanism to buy oil from Iran and pay it back with India?
- Every time they see us, the Indians say they are looking for a way to set up a bilateral system before we complain.
Can the State Department not suggest a solution, roadmap or method?
- The problem is that our proposals are not a newspaper. One of the problems the Department of State and Economic Diplomacy is having is that we cannot explain what we are doing. But you can be sure that we did not sit idle.
* In an interview with one of the European countries' ambassadors in Iran, he was quoted as saying why Iran says three European countries when it comes to fulfilling its economic obligations, but makes no mention of China and Russia. These two countries are also members of the Brotherhood and can contribute to Iran's economic gain. In recent days a report has been published in Bloomberg that Iran has been able to increase its oil sales figure by ship-to-ship shift. China has been Iran's main buyer of oil before the boycott. To what extent can China now oppose Iran's zero-sum oil policy pursued by the United States?
- As I said, Americans threaten their allies like Europeans when they trade with us in the most severe way, but that doesn't mean they don't threaten others. They threaten their allies with the most difficult of ways. The Chinese and Russians are no exception. But countries are more likely to hear and depend on the United States. The less their dependence on the United States is, the less they will naturally listen to Americans. At the same time, if they define other interests for themselves and in relation to Iran, they will be less likely to hear from the United States. We believe that the Chinese, Russians and various countries around the world have done their utmost to maintain their relationship with us, and we thank our partners for this.
* Do you mean Europe?
- Europe tried very hard, but so far it has not been able to do anything.
* So we don't thank Europe.
- We can't say we don't thank you, we're silent right now to see if they can do something.
Public opinion has a negative view of the trade relationship with China and Russia. It is even said that trade with Iran is beneficial to China and Russia and is more beneficial when sanctioned. There is a view among the public that trade with Iran is cheaper and cheaper for the Chinese during sanctions. As Deputy Foreign Minister for Economic Diplomacy, how would you answer the question of whether we benefit from an economic relationship with a country like China or do we have to?
- Today, boycotts in the world are not meant to be stopped, but when you are boycotted, your costs go up. The world has a lot of pores and countries in the world need a business relationship so they find their way. But the cost is going up for the country under sanctions. Now your sides are Chinese, Brazilian, Turkmen, European. Your costs will increase because you are under sanctions. Sanctions mean raising costs and seizing opportunities. Competition is very difficult for you when you are boycotted. So boycott means cost.
* But you are one of those people who say in your speech that sanctions are opportunities.
- For an economy like ours that needs reform, it can be an opportunity.
* Which one is heavier? Opportunity or Threat?
- In any case, the boycott will hold the economy back. That means you could have jumped, but today you can only walk. That you say the one who is on our side is more profitable to us is because your costs are high. Sanctions mean raising costs. Yet today, the United States knows that some of our scientific achievements have been under sanctions. Our greatest scientific achievements have been during the boycott. Remember that in the first sanctions, at the beginning of the sanctions we had 9,000 and at the end of the sanctions 19,000 centrifuges. Are we comparable to the past in terms of military capabilities, capabilities, capabilities, innovations? no. We did all this during the boycott. The boycott was an opportunity for us to reflect on our own capabilities. It means opportunity. But was it also cost effective? Yes. The war was also costly. The war had enormous spiritual and material costs. Some of the costs we could never afford to pay were the youths who defended our country. But the war has brought us to the military realm that today is our nation's honor.
* Following the Secretary of State's visit to China, media speculation has surfaced about a number of comprehensive strategic agreements between the two countries, which the Foreign Minister denied some of the speculations. Do you have any plans to publish the text of this roadmap that we have proposed to China for 25 years of cooperation? Can you say what were the main headlines of this Iranian offer to China?
- Firstly, the material on the sites and virtual news is, as you say, the media speculation and speculation that has been made and we do not approve or disprove it. In my opinion, China is a developing country and the cooperation potential between us and China is very high. China is a country that is part of Asia and has not come to Asia more than 20,000 kilometers. We are also part of Asia so we are interested in working with China. It is natural to offer suggestions to the Chinese for long-term cooperation. The Americans are leaving the area, but China cannot leave. China has no choice but to live here because it is part of Asia. Of course China is in East Asia and we are in West Asia, but where is the US located? One day he decides to come and one day he decides to go. One day he says he stays in Syria, one day he gets up and goes. The United States comes to Afghanistan one day with NATO, and one day it decides to go. So today no one trusts Westerners who have entered Asia.
* Do you confirm that we have made major suggestions to China in this Roadmap?
- What I can tell you is that we have great ideas for extensive cooperation with China.
* And ensure that the interests of both countries are met.
Nothing in the world can be guaranteed. In the world today, it is your power that guarantees your interests.
* There is much public concern about the issue of drug embargo and import. Previously it was said that the Swiss were looking for initiatives to define the canal for the smooth export of drugs and food to Iran. Of course, there is no rumor about this and the Swiss initiative does not appear to have been implemented. What advice did the State Department have on this, especially with European countries?
- The Americans have done their best to exert pressure on the Iranian people. I want to promise you, as I told you at the beginning of the discussion, they have a way to boycott, and we have a hundred ways to get around boycott. So it's not a concern in the long and short term. Of course, boycott means cost, but there is no stopping it. No one in today's world can stop the flow of goods. Not only the US, but others cannot, either. In the short and long term, we will not face serious problems in securing supplies and medicines. Fortunately now, with the jump in our non-oil market, we are finding markets that are even usable for our oil sales. I am sure there will be no problem in the short and long term. What is very important and must be noted is the cognition we have to find in the United States. Americans are giving humanitarian slogans that their hearts are burning with the Iranian nation, but today most of the sanctions are being inflicted on the middle and weak. The same people who chanted slogans, we want to find a way, and the sanctions are aimed at the government, but you see, by the way, they work with the people. The pressures on the nation are moderate and weak.
We have no worries about the future, our hardest times were in 97 and harder in 98, and today you are witnessing what we are going through. If we can more accurately address the economic weaknesses and limitations that sometimes exist in our laws and regulations, we will have a much easier time looking at export and production in the country.
Dedicate our final question to the adventurous FATF story. We know little or nothing about the State Department's approval or disapproval of the remaining bills, but the new deadline given to Iran will certainly make the job harder, and it seems that the return of punitive measures could make matters worse for Iran under sanctions.
- One of the warnings the State Department has given at various meetings is the FATF debate. It is like asking me what you think about traveling.
I say traveling is great, but I am against passports. Anyone who wants to get out of their own country is an internationally agreed requirement to have a passport. FATF today means having a passport. If the Iranian banking system wants to make any connection with the world's banking system, whether small or large, it is FATF. This year the visa was lifted between us and Iraq due to political friendship between the two countries, but you must have a passport to travel. Do. Your passport is your identity outside your borders. Today the FATF and its regulations are a condition of presenceOur banking system is out of bounds. Whether it's in Afghanistan, Syria and China or in Europe. Unfortunately, this concept has not been addressed. FATF is your tool to get out of your banking system. If we can't get through this situation safely, our banking system will be completely paralyzed. That means you will not even be able to be present in friendly and neighbor countries in the banking arena.
You can travel to friendly countries and your first requirement is a passport. Some of me have the question that if I get a passport can I go to France? No, it doesn't mean that. If you want to travel and get out of your own country, the first step is to have a passport. If you intend to go to a particular country, you have another requirement, that you must obtain a visa there. Whether or not you get a visa is another matter. But you need a passport to leave the country. FATF means getting a passport to get your banking system off the ground.
If we are not able to pass the FATF in the few months that we are given the opportunity, you can be confident that the country's banking system will face a serious crisis.
* Some critics say that in a boycott, observing FATF standards would mean turning to the other side about ways to circumvent sanctions.
- Tell those who say that most intelligence in the country claims that most information is transmitted through mobile phones abroad. It includes everything from details, overviews, photos, pictures, information. Fortunately, our intelligence agencies have always ordered us not to use these advanced mobiles in particular. Because your photos, sound, images, and even your behavior are observable and sendable. Those who say the FATF is making the country go out of business, are they willing to hand over their mobile phones?
* Do you also warn of the consequences of non-compliance with FATF standards in meetings you have with leaders of the system or with different security agencies and ministries?
- Yes, at the last State Department meeting to justify, I expressed all my views. The FATF is not a requirement but a necessity to continue. Countries that are even friendlier to China have told us that after this deadline, they will not be able to make any bank transfers to us, whether or not the bank is sanctioned.
* One of the criticisms is why Secretary of State Mike Pompeo insists that we approve and approve these two remaining bills. If all the bills by chance are finally tightened on Iran, why does the US insist that Iran finish it?
- We haven't seen what they insist on, then we don't want to say. Or else they say they don't want it done and we say we want it done. We have to look at our own destiny and our laws. See how many countries are now members of the FATF? All the world are members.
* It may be easier to say if some countries are not members.
- Yes, even one or two remaining countries are begging for membership. The FATF debate is very important. Of course, other organizations need to expertly address this issue. The Ministry of Economic Affairs and Finance, the Central Bank, the organizations that will be more specialized in dealing with them. We are now given many three and four-month opportunities, and lasting up to one year, two years to four years. Today and at the last meeting they announced that February is the end of the month. If we do not pass it, it is like getting rid of the country's banking system, which has been badly damaged by sanctions.
